reviews.text: Coogler keeps Black Panther: Wakanda Forever absorbing and coherent, with a thoroughly thought-out set of antagonists and a chest-swelling tribute to Chadwick Boseman, giving the characters and the audience the space to grieve him.
reviews.author: Christina Newland

reviews.text: Rather than position Namor as a man who suffered an unfortunate, but centuries-old, part of nation-building, Wakanda Forever reminds us that imperial powers remain at work today.
reviews.author: Joe George

reviews.text: From his [Ryan Coogler] dynamic vision of recreating Namor’s origin to his exploration of themes of Indigenous Latin cultures, Wakanda Forever is an innovative and refreshing take on superhero lore.
reviews.author: Nadya Martinez

reviews.text: The entire film aches with a melancholy at the passing of Boseman but it feels like a film that wants to embrace him and move on in his memory rather than wallow in the sadness of the loss.
reviews.author: Paul Klein

reviews.text: The pacing, demons, and storytelling monsters take down the film.
reviews.author: Shawn Edwards

reviews.text: “Wakanda Forever” is an epic, emotional and profound film that examines the impact of collective anguish.
reviews.author: Lee Zumpe

reviews.text: Apart from the overarching themes of death, loss, revenge and owning your destiny, and all the eye-popping battles atop barnacle-crusted whales and dolphins no less, Black Panther 2 works in the smaller, intimate moments too.
reviews.author: Mini Anthikad-Chhibber

reviews.text: This was a fantastic way to wrap out Phase 4 of the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
reviews.author: Christian Eulinberg

reviews.text: Coogler uses the sequel to similarly popularize Mayan Futurism with the sumptuous introduction of the Talokans, which makes the Wakandans seem quotidian in comparison.
reviews.author: Sarah Vincent

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever rises to a difficult challenge with strong characters, superb acting and visual effects that are a marvel.
reviews.author: Rick Bentley

reviews.text: “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever” is a powerful treatise on grieving, and how that process can seep into every thought and action, even subconsciously.
reviews.author: Kevin Slane

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever may not quite measure up to its predecessor, but it leaves a proud, beautiful, silent tribute to the legacy of Chadwick Boseman, telling an emotionally powerful, resonant story about how grief can truly be love persevering.
reviews.author: Manuel São Bento

reviews.text: Plays with ideas and characters that initially intrigue, but drowns them in tiresome excessive Marvel lore and universe expansion.
reviews.author: Hector A. Gonzalez

reviews.text: This sequel acts as an uplifting reminder that grief is real and losing someone close doesn't mean losing all hope in the power of community.
reviews.author: Matthew Creith

reviews.text: Beautiful tribute about Grief & the cycle of violence. Epic in almost all standards but slower in pacing to tell a different kind of story in the MCU.
reviews.author: Zach Pope

reviews.text: As evocative as it is in the film, light pierces through every shot, every storyline, and every performance, making it a remarkable love letter to grief and healing.
reviews.author: Gissane Sophia

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever is the best Black Panther sequel it could have been, acting both as a tribute to Boseman and a poignant story about change and rebirth.
reviews.author: Serena Seghedoni

reviews.text: We deserve a story about Africanness and Diasporic Blackness that’s not hampered by the white gaze that would refuse us peace, justice, unity and vengeance. In the MCU, no matter who’s at the helm, that’s just not possible.
reviews.author: Brooke Obie

reviews.text: Black Panther Wakanda Forever is undoubtedly one of the worst movies of the year and a clear indication for Marvel to start making movies again instead of peddling products that promote future products.
reviews.author: Pramit Chatterjee

reviews.text: "Black Panther: Wakanda Forever" doesn't have the punch that the first movie did, but how could it? Sequels rarely do.
reviews.author: Matthew Passantino

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is constrained by its genre and studio from being a great film. It is nonetheless an entertaining one with intriguing characters and intense visuals.
reviews.author: Kevin Fox Jr.

reviews.text: A disappointment, especially compared to its excellent predecessor.
reviews.author: Matt Brunson

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever is very long and needed an intermission. You know it’s a Marvel movie because it’s steeped in boredom, with every scene threatening to not end.
reviews.author: A.S. Hamrah

reviews.text: lack Panther: Wakanda Forever has the usual MCU mix of humour and fun action scenes but it's severely lacking a charismatic lead performer, and some of the lazy writing during the final third was frankly embarrassing. One of the weaker MCU efforts.
reviews.author: David Hogan

reviews.text: Its pacing may feel a bit undercalculated as some scenes consume too much screen time, though unsure footing can be forgiven by closed chapters and new beginnings.
reviews.author: Annie Banks

reviews.text: The sheer volume of subplots makes the finished product rather unwieldy, struggling to maintain the tight thematic focus of ‘Black Panther.’
reviews.author: Gavia Baker-Whitelaw

reviews.text: If there’s one compelling callback to the lost T’Challa that really works, it’s the Queen who has seemingly lost a good chunk of her family and now is faced with its greatest threat. Bassett is the brightest light here.
reviews.author: Dan Buffa

reviews.text: There's already something kind of special about a movie that's largely about grief being made as an act of grieving.
reviews.author: Vera Wylde

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever tries to be a tribute and a recapitulation and a cog in the ever-grinding Marvel machine. The result is sometimes moving and intermittently watchable. But it’s a also a mess—not least in its politics.
reviews.author: Noah Berlatsky

reviews.text: Feels like a very fitting memorial to a friend who died unexpectedly from a horrible disease, far too young.
reviews.author: Peter Martin

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever doesn't show, it tells. This is, simply and plainly, an affront to cinematic language. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Erick Estrada

reviews.text: The tribute here is heartfelt, but the spirit of the man and the character sometimes get lost in all the bric-a-brac of the Marvel machine... the film lands on a triumphant note of succession, as it must– the gods inside and above the narrative demand it.
reviews.author: John Serba

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is a good film, that much is certain. At the same time it fails to quite match the extraordinary impact of the original Black Panther.
reviews.author: Grant Watson

reviews.text: A beautiful tribute, an attempt at every turn to honor and recognize Chadwick Boseman's importance... they meant so well, but as a film there are a lot of misses here.
reviews.author: Aaron White

reviews.text: A compelling, beautiful story about family and carrying on a loved one’s legacy...
reviews.author: Felix Vasquez Jr.

reviews.text: A superhero movie with soul.
reviews.author: Kip Mooney

reviews.text: You can hear a pin drop in the first five minutes of Wakanda Forever. It’s intense and doesn’t let go of wrestling with loss, the cycle of violence and how we respond to it all throughout its running time. Even with that, this film is a vibe!
reviews.author: Kevin Sampson

reviews.text: In this meta way, there is this audience recognition that the actors on screen aren’t just going through the motions here and what you’re witnessing isn’t a performance of grief, but an actual show of grief.
reviews.author: Joseph Garcia

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever entertains but also disappoints, perhaps because we expect so much more.
reviews.author: Diane Carson

reviews.text: Angela Bassett is in control with a cinematic elegance that can't be taught or directed - it's in her DNA making this sequel another reason for audiences to cross arms proclaiming Wakanda Forever with pride and tribute to Chadwick Boseman.
reviews.author: Carla Renata

reviews.text: Tenoch Huerta had his breakthrough role not only in Hollywood’s massive Marvel Cinematic Universe, but also in the MCU’s grand Black Panther story...
reviews.author: Fletcher Peters

reviews.text: This soulful sequel teams an emotional tribute to late star Chadwick Boseman with some spectacular visual action. A maturity milestone for the Marvel Cinematic Universe, starring Angela Bassett and Winston Duke.
reviews.author: Larushka Ivan-Zadeh

reviews.text: Where The Avengers: Endgame lacked in its depiction of post-traumatic psychological exploration, Black Panther: Wakanda Forever makes up for in its examination of grief as a motivator and the difficulty of moving on from a core part of one’s own identity.
reviews.author: Wesley Lovell

reviews.text: Though it will be remembered for the strong performances by Wright and Bassett, and the way it powerfully honors Boseman, the storytelling is standard and lacking the same strength.
reviews.author: Erin Maxwell

reviews.text: As a tribute to Chadwick Boseman, Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is a beautiful remembrance of the man, the talent, and the character under his brief stewardship. As a movie, though, the results become a bit shakier.
reviews.author: Rob Hunter

reviews.text: For the most part, Coogler balances the film’s onscreen and offscreen needs extremely well. But three areas didn’t quite work for me.
reviews.author: Carolyn Hinds

reviews.text: From veteran Angela Bassett’s emotional speeches to the introduction of young genius Riri Williams (Dominique Heart), there’s plenty to be optimistic about in this crowded but emotionally satisfying Black Panther return.
reviews.author: Victoria Luxford

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever pays homage to Boseman's legacy and succeeds in taking the saga into new and exciting directions. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Rene Sanchez

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever falls noticeably short of its predecessor in many respects except for an unnecessarily bloated 161-minute running time that could easily have trimmed with a few slashes of the title character’s vibranium-enriched claws.
reviews.author: Damon Smith

reviews.text: It risks letting women handle all the heroics, not a favorite idea among many fanboys—but an approach that succeeds.
reviews.author: Robin Holabird

reviews.text: It may not be the most exciting superhero flick, but Wakanda Forever makes up for its shortcomings with touching drama and terrific acting.
reviews.author: Sameen Amer

reviews.text: Director Ryan Coogler tries valiantly to make this all work and it does here and there. In the end his considerable gifts are arguably better suited to grounded human drama than superhero pictures.
reviews.author: Nathaniel Rogers

reviews.text: Much like the Star Wars galaxy or Tolkien's Middle Earth, Wakanda is becoming the realest kind of fictional place, one that inspires collaboration by artists and writers and ordinary fans.
reviews.author: Kathryn Reklis

reviews.text: It's a pretty compelling narrative with the perfect amount of fuel to really make us question how far off T'Challa's path grief has taken Shuri. Ultimately a narrative bridge for the MCU, it always strives to deliver upon its own drama first.
reviews.author: Jared Mobarak

reviews.text: “Black Panther,” in fact, is on a higher plan than most. It creates a world, inhabits it and gives reasons for its people’s actions. It’s a bold mission statement that’s largely due to Coogler. He makes the 160 minutes worthwhile.
reviews.author: Bruce R. Miller

reviews.text: Like its predecessor, Wakanda Forever often feels more like it's occupying its own space than advancing the larger narrative.
reviews.author: Pete Vonder Haar

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever offers a lot of surprises, plenty of action, and a fitting tribute to Boseman as well as to Wakanda. Get your passport stamped and return to Wakanda because it is Well Worth Watching,
reviews.author: Reginald Ponder

reviews.text: …Wakanda Forever may well have fans, but it’s hard to imagine anyone who could prefer this bloated, confusing film to the far more effective original….
reviews.author: Eddie Harrison

reviews.text: After the death of Chadwick Boseman, the makers of the superhero movie had to reimagine the series. The result makes for a sobering and affecting sequel.
reviews.author: Stephen Kearse

reviews.text: Tries to do too much with too much movie — but when it stuns, it's stunning.
reviews.author: Matt Donato

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever makes for a melancholy conclusion to phase four.
reviews.author: Eric Marchen

reviews.text: A moving and entertaining superhero action movie that forges a bright new path for the Black Panther legacy. It’s the follow-up that fans needed.
reviews.author: Louisa Moore

reviews.text: There is indeed a  smattering of the character development. No doubt all abustle, some critics just understandably might’ve missed the transmogrifications. (Hint: Look for someone putting on a mask and another going all hue-y.)
reviews.author: Brandon Judell

reviews.text: It’s generally well-paced and features an excellent lead performance from Wright and an Oscar-worthy performance from Bassett. For a movie with a complicated hole to dig itself out of, this sequel rises victorious.
reviews.author: Jonathan Sim

reviews.text: Kind of a mixed bag, but worth seeing if you liked the first one.
reviews.author: Christy Lemire

reviews.text: This film, leading into phase five, makes it as symbolic as it is impactful. It expands the MCU’s diversity through sheer authenticity.
reviews.author: Frantz Jerome

reviews.text: Like the first Black Panther movie, Black Panther: Wakanda Forever asks us to consider why and when vengeance is futile, and what the difference is between an antihero and an anti villain.
reviews.author: Kimberly Reyes

reviews.text: Not only is it a powerful tribute to a star whose screen presence could never be duplicated; it also points the way forward for Marvel, positing a future where the formula can be bent in directions that don't always dutifully fill a mold...
reviews.author: Rubén Rosario

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever is best as a love letter to a fallen friend, and as a kind of conduit for public grief.
reviews.author: Sarah Marrs

reviews.text: In the end, Wakanda Forever is about a choice. Do you rage? Or do you accept and let go. Saying farewell without forgetting.  Moving on.  That Coogler managed to embed that in a Marvel movie is a minor miracle and fitting tribute to the talent we lost.
reviews.author: Eli Glasner

reviews.text: While suffering from exhausting connections to the ever-expanding Marvel Cinematic Universe, Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is an emotional tribute to Chadwick Boseman, with an exploration of grief easily capable of reaching the audience’s heart.
reviews.author: Diego Peralta

reviews.text: A palpable low point for the Marvel Cinematic Universe...
reviews.author: David Nusair

reviews.text: Finally breaking the tyranny of the superhero blockbuster structure, filmmaker Ryan Coogler makes an unusually affecting sequel that takes a darker and far more emotional approach to storytelling.
reviews.author: Rich Cline

reviews.text: You may not be ready for everything that Black Panther is going to throw at you. It is unapologetically Black, African, colorful, and poignant.
reviews.author: MontiLee Stormer

reviews.text: ...the positive side, the performances are strong and the visual effects are outstanding.  But great effects do not always a great movie make (I’m looking at you, “Avatar”) and the humanity that Boseman brought to the title character is greatly missed.
reviews.author: Michael A. Smith

reviews.text: his film could have been tone-deaf or insensitive. It could have simply not existed at all. The fact that it does exist and is a solid cinematic experience is, on its face, fairly miraculous.
reviews.author: Tim Brennan

reviews.text: Overall, the film is solid with a few passages worth going to the theater for. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Ruben Peralta Rigaud

reviews.text: Angela Bassett and Letitia Wright are stand outs as audiences can feel the pain they are going through from losing their beloved star and friend.
reviews.author: Susan Kamyab

reviews.text: Feels overstuffed, filled with interesting ideas and possibilities that never fully come into focus.
reviews.author: Mattie Lucas

reviews.text: You can still see the bones of the original concept, poking jaggedly through the flesh of the story, and meshing not at all with the new material about grieving and coming to grips with loss.
reviews.author: Tim Brayton

reviews.text: This is a great film that does have it's flaws, specifically its length. This was a heavy film that has a lot of deep meaning and themes that might go over the general audience's head. The performances and costumes were fantastic.
reviews.author: Justin Brown

reviews.text: The movie is very solid despite being 20 minutes too long. Namor was a fantastic villain/anti-hero. The costume designs were incredible as were the performances, particularly Letitia Wright and Angela Bassett. The latter should absolutely be nominated!
reviews.author: Brandon Collins

reviews.text: This is the first Marvel that dealt with death and change in the most realistic way. "Wakanda Forever" takes this genre to another level because of the performances, world building and emotional gravity of the story.
reviews.author: Tatiana Albandos

reviews.text: The plot is sometimes messy, with many moving parts, but the film gives its actors—especially Wakanda’s formidable women—powerful performances and moments to shine.
reviews.author: Valerie Kalfrin

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever never reaches the highs of its predecessor or some of Marvel’s best. It’s still an impressive achievement from Coogler and his cast, all of whom seemingly pour their personal experience of losing Boseman into their roles.
reviews.author: Maria Lattila

reviews.text: While 'Wakanda Forever' is ultimately a very good superhero film, it's hard not to think of what it could have been.
reviews.author: Josh Davis

reviews.text: Nobody expects Shakespearean dialogue in these films, but the script and the plot should not be this crummy.
reviews.author: John McDonald

reviews.text: It is a creatively made sequel as well as a fitting tribute to Chadwick Boseman
reviews.author: Jackie K. Cooper

reviews.text: When the film lets all the crushing pressures of the MCU narrative take a backseat, it’s a wonderful film, worthy of Chadwick Boseman’s legacy and a strong representation of the diversity and beauty that can be possible in the superhero genre.
reviews.author: TK Burton

reviews.text: The MCU’s mechanics are too oppressive to allow for true mournful meditation.
reviews.author: Adam Kempenaar

reviews.text: It's a fitting tribute to a beloved actor and the character he played.
reviews.author: Linda Cook

reviews.text: What results is an undoubtedly muted and depressing film, with almost all of the issues that plagued the production manifesting themselves on screen and having a deleterious impact.
reviews.author: Nick Johnston

reviews.text: With a sleeker script (Wakanda Forever runs 161 minutes), Wright and Huerta Mejía might have owned the sequel the way Boseman and Jordan owned the original, but their performances get lost in a rush of bland battles and baffling detours.
reviews.author: Bennett Campbell Ferguson

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is a film that works well as a respectfully choreographed and undeniably dignified farewell to its leading man -- less so as a lesson in coherent, big-budget storytelling.
reviews.author: Chris Wasser

reviews.text: Marvel has painted yet another three-dimensional "villain," if you want to call him that, so I think Marvel and Ryan Coogler and the writers did a good job at conveying that once again.
reviews.author: Tony Baker

reviews.text: Ryan Coogler handles the vast story and scope of Black Panther: Wakanda Forever with impressive skill and pulls off a feat that a less skilled director would have left muddled.
reviews.author: Theolin Tembo

reviews.text: As a tribute to the Black Panther -- the late Chadwick Boseman -- Wakanda Forever is incredibly moving. It also has some astonishing women dominating the big screen in the best possible way.
reviews.author: Kate Rodger

reviews.text: The first Black Panther... set a bar Wakanda Forever didn't come close to matching. But taken on its own terms, as a superhero sequel tasked with serving an unusually wide range of needs, it stands as a different kind of accomplishment.
reviews.author: Albert Samaha

reviews.text: Wow! You’ll say that over and over again as this mind-blowing, superhero epic unfolds. Wow!
reviews.author: Dwight Brown

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is certainly a lot of movie and a fitting tribute to the legacy of Chadwick Boseman. While some mileage may vary with the pacing and plottiness, the movie does provide a thrilling entry in the saga of Wakanda.
reviews.author: Terence Johnson

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever may not be the perfect Marvel movie, but [it] prove its worthiness as a bridge – not merely between Phase 4 and Phase 5... but from the bleakness of loss to a stable place from which a new generation can move forward.
reviews.author: Melanie McFarland

reviews.text: A history lesson lurks below the explosions, clashing swords and other Superhero Spectacles.
reviews.author: Charles Mudede

reviews.text: It’s certainly not the worst Marvel film (remember Eternals? Me neither), and there are moments of true excellence—particularly Angela Bassett’s performance of rage and grief. But it’s disappointing to see the promising setup fizzle.
reviews.author: Matt Baume

reviews.text: Despite these issues, and the overlong running time (two hours and 41 minutes) this is an entertaining superhero movie, with some effective dramatic elements.
reviews.author: Robert Roten

reviews.text: Returning director Coogler has defied the odds to marshal something that satisfies the demands of the Marvel production line, expands on the original’s themes of colonialism, and is sensitive tribute to his friend.
reviews.author: Christopher Machell

reviews.text: It feels authored by Coogler, combining a popular, approachably light touch with a radical and emotional heart.
reviews.author: Nick Hasted

reviews.text: ... There is real violence, real loss, no clear right, and no clear wrong. It is as complex as real life is, good writing from Coogler and his screenplay collaborator Joe Robert Cole.
reviews.author: Cris Kennedy

reviews.text: The most unlikely Marvel film ever... they take these really small bites of grieving, and they can extend them and live in them, and still be able to tell an engaging action-oriented story.
reviews.author: tt stern-enzi

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is not flawless, but it combines celebration, send-off and rambunctious legacy with the utmost respect — without allowing that respect to gum up the works and turn the whole into a wake.
reviews.author: Tom Shone

reviews.text: Completely unfocused, everything is important so nothing ends up being so.  [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Jorge Loser

reviews.text: Chadwick Boseman and T’Challa’s absence looms large throughout the ‘Black Panther’ sequel, most of all as it relates to Shuri, who grapples with loss in nuanced and unexpected ways.
reviews.author: Miles Surrey

reviews.text: It may not send the audience into raptures, but it does nearly everything that a sequel is expected to.
reviews.author: Saibal Chatterjee

reviews.text: Considering the heavy burden that Coogler carried, the movie qualifies as a success -- even if we grumble a little.
reviews.author: Robert Denerstein

reviews.text: Coogler and Co. managed to process their own profound senses of loss in order to achieve what had once seemed to be an unachievable task in and of itself: putting together a film that could rival Black Panther and double as a beautiful tribute to Boseman.
reviews.author: Daniel Chin

reviews.text: A blockbuster that brings maturity back to the MCU, downplaying the comedic factor and successfully combining geopolitical thriller, overtones of war movies and the standards of contemporary superhero cinema.
reviews.author: Víctor López G.

reviews.text: "Wakanda Forever" exists within an apparatus that will never allow the creatives working inside it the freedom and space to make it anything more than the best possible compromise.
reviews.author: Dominic Griffin

reviews.text: It’s a lot for one movie to take on, but thanks to Coogler’s graceful storytelling and the efforts of a stellar cast, the film shoulders that burden and then some, delivering one of the most exhilarating blockbuster experiences of the year.
reviews.author: Matthew Jackson

reviews.text: Of course, the sequel was never going to be as good as Black Panther, but the film allows its characters and the audience to process the death of T’Challa and Boseman with some catharsis.
reviews.author: Brian Eggert

reviews.text: Too downer for my taste, but It's a good film, although editing & pacing a little bit off, specially around 2nd act. Acting is top notch, with Angela Basset the absolute MVP. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Jorge Rivera Rubio

reviews.text: Writer-director Ryan Coogler's sequel, led by an excellent ensemble of women, pays tribute to the hard loss of Boseman/T'Challa by exploring how grief (and revenge) can be all-consuming.
reviews.author: Sandie Angulo Chen

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is one of the most impressive films in the entire MCU and a fitting end to a chapter exploring grief and how it can transform us.
reviews.author: Nicole Ackman

reviews.text: Much better looking and more tasteful than most Marvel movies, but how many supposedly "anti-colonial" comic book movies are we going to make where the big baddy is another oppressed person?
reviews.author: Vincent Mancini

reviews.text: A film about loss and grief. It has a great hole at its center, but the filmmakers have embraced that emptiness, and let it become part of the film’s fabric.
reviews.author: Jeffrey M. Anderson

reviews.text: Ryan Coogler's sequel mourns Boseman, can't deliver suitable successor.
reviews.author: Christian Toto

reviews.text: The turbulence of grief is present and uncensored, destabilising the film’s focus – one can’t help but forgive any stumble entirely. Besides, Wright binds together every thread of Wakanda Forever with a magnetic and emotionally raw performance.
reviews.author: Laura Potier

reviews.text: Considering how light and breezy the recent MCU has felt, it’s nice and refreshing to get something more serious-minded.
reviews.author: Keith Garlington

reviews.text: After a solid prologue, every single decision either misses an opportunity or pulls its punches. Especially when given the chance to elevate its female protagonists it then gives all the dynamics to its new villain in an overlong but well undercut sequel.
reviews.author: Erik Childress

reviews.text: Writer/director Ryan Coogler managed to not only find a way to get the best-case scenario out of an impossibly bleak situation but to do so in a way that exceeds expectations and confronts those dark conditions head-on.
reviews.author: Rob Dean

reviews.text: As a finale to Marvel’s up-and-down Phase 4, it doesn’t hold up, but that’s not why we’re here. As a tribute to Chadwick Boseman and a story in how one moves forward following devastating tragedy, Wakanda Forever hits the spot.
reviews.author: Rhys Bowen Jones

reviews.text: As a heartbreaking farewell to Boseman and his character, the film mostly succeeds. Which is good, because the rest is as frustratingly messy as the MCU has ever been.
reviews.author: Nicolás Delgadillo

reviews.text: Coogler calibrates well – we share a sense of heartbreak, but are not so overwhelmed by it that we can’t take pleasure in this imaginative adventure.
reviews.author: Abbie Bernstein

reviews.text: Anchored by strong performances and chemistry carried over from the previous movie, Wakanda Forever argues for Wakanda as a world power.
reviews.author: Candice McMillan

reviews.text: As good as Black Panther, yet Coogler & Co.’s balancing of Boseman’s legacy with a fresh, new adventure is a different kind of achievement.
reviews.author: Edwin Arnaudin

reviews.text: I find I respect Coogler’s sequel more than I actually enjoyed it, and that’s as disappointing a turn of events as any I could have imagined.
reviews.author: Sara Michelle Fetters

reviews.text: ...perhaps one of the more melancholy superhero movies in the MCU’s history.
reviews.author: Michael Ward

reviews.text: A reverent and touching tribute, honors the past and breathes a new hope into the future, leaving a legacy...  An emotional voyage and forever work of wonder.
reviews.author: Nathalia Aryani

reviews.text: A superhero movie missing its superhero, 'Black Panther: Wakanda Forever' compensates with a compelling villain.
reviews.author: André Hereford

reviews.text: [Ryan] Coogler delivers a welcome, yet somber, return to Wakanda with an exceptional cast to explore the many facets of grief, revenge, and the long-last effects of colonialism through a fantastical lens.
reviews.author: Maggie Lovitt

reviews.text: Excessive yet impressive - and YOU MUST STAY through the credits for a 'surprise' or miss an intriguing glimpse into the franchise's future.
reviews.author: Susan Granger

reviews.text: While it lacks the cohesiveness and mythic force of Black Panther, Wakanda Forever introduces new and fascinating directions and questions to explore, with evocative world-building and entertaining action.
reviews.author: Ayelet Dekel

reviews.text: What it amounts to is a new, large sweeping epic from Ryan Coogler, who delivers a more grounded sequel in the Black Panther universe. Wakanda Forever honors, mends, and excites.
reviews.author: Leo Brady

reviews.text: The emotional core is raw, credible and affecting.
reviews.author: Wendy Ide

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever is a moving tribute to Boseman’s legacy, and, whilst the movie struggles under the weight of its own swollen story, it delivers when it needed to most.
reviews.author: Matt Hudson

reviews.text: It is these character transformations which will determine what you get out of Black Panther: Wakanda Forever... If you want an emotional journey for characters a lot of us have grown to care about than it more than suffices
reviews.author: Rachel Wagner

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever doesn't reach the first Black Panther's greatness but it succeeds as a beautiful, emotional tribute to Chadwick Boseman, while honoring the powerful women of Wakanda.
reviews.author: Ruth Maramis

reviews.text: Coogler is the best director working in the comic book space.
reviews.author: Chris McCoy

reviews.text: Tthe brilliance of the piece comes in how co-writer and director Ryan Coogler, back from 2018's epic (in every way imaginable) screen original, manages to fill in the somber blanks left by the sad absence of his legitimate bright light, Chadwick Boseman.
reviews.author: John Urbancich

reviews.text: At points rich and bold, fiercely projecting strong female black power into the world especially, Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is a film to be admired first, enjoyed second.
reviews.author: Tony Black

reviews.text: Although it lacked the rich symbolism of the first film and went into a more conventional comic story direction, its emotion cannot be dismissed. And interestingly, another gap in its atmosphere was the one they most memorialized ... Chadwick Boseman. RIP
reviews.author: Patrick McDonald

reviews.text: The opening and closing sequences of Wakanda Forever will make your heart ache. But at 2hrs 41mins, this is also one of the longest films in the MCU. And there are long stretches in it which border on boredom. I was weepy but also weary.
reviews.author: Anupama Chopra

reviews.text: The treatment of Boseman's death is sensitive and tasteful and the movie introduces an interesting idea about the shared pain between Namor and Shuri. Unfortunately, there is too much going on for the actual plot to leave any impact.
reviews.author: Nathaniel Muir

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever is a Black Panther, Avatar, and Aquaman sequel all rolled into one with a stunning display of female superpowers.
reviews.author: Dustin Chase

reviews.text: Coogler wasn’t about to let this film be anything but the audacious, downright bleak, ultimately cathartic journey these characters, this cast and crew, and this audience needed to take to really process the pain.
reviews.author: Cory Woodroof

reviews.text: Ryan Coogler leans into the expansive chronicles of the Black Panther, offering a treatise on grief and renewal.
reviews.author: Ro Moore

reviews.text: The intention is all there, to address [Boseman’s death] and be respectful, but it goes overboard. The film spends far too much time mourning T’Challa and not enough exploring how moving forward impacts these characters.
reviews.author: James Marsh

reviews.text: Amid overtly reckoning with absence, Coogler still has a top-notch cast drawing eyeballs towards his vibrant imagery, but his picture is also burdened with MCU bloat and mechanics, and infuriating bet-hedging.
reviews.author: Sarah Ward

reviews.text: Coogler pulls off an incredible feat, despite some story stumbles, creating a superhero film that is emotionally affecting, politically and culturally urgent, and that pays loving tribute not just to T’Challa but Chadwick Boseman too.
reviews.author: Katie Walsh

reviews.text: When I'm getting more choked up over the death of a character from a dumb Fast & the Furious movie than I am for a character I genuinely care about, something's wrong. Wakanda Forever takes its time being a disappointment.
reviews.author: Adam Olinger

reviews.text: This movie serves as a tribute to Chadwick Boseman as well as bringing the characters of Wakanda into a bigger, messier, and more complex world.
reviews.author: Kevin Carr

reviews.text: It’s a little overstuffed, and some elements that are clearly there to tie it into the larger direction of the MCU could be cut entirely... However, it’s still a grand, vibrant epic and a worthy series continuation.
reviews.author: Abby Olcese

reviews.text: While difficult to take seriously at times, ‘Wakanda Forever’ remains a fine addition to the MCU, offering the most food for thought than any other Phase 4 movie.
reviews.author: Preston Barta

reviews.text: Has any other social group ever had its history diminished to comic-book trivia and then encouraged to take that insult as a compliment?
reviews.author: Armond White

reviews.text: Chadwick Boseman's death creates a couple problems the picture can't quite get around, but it's overall an ambitious, entertaining chapter in the MCU.
reviews.author: Mike McGranaghan

reviews.text: The message comes first. Meanwhile, the pure entertainment that's so essential for a comic-based super production gets buried by ideas and vindications (that aren't even entirely deep) in a film that went past its running time. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Javier Ocaña

reviews.text: After a spate of manic superhero blockbusters that ricocheted from one digital spectacle to another, this one takes its time with character and plot but doesn’t develop either to any satisfying degree.
reviews.author: Kyle Smith

reviews.text: Coogler and Cole give Angela Bassett, Letitia Wright, and Danai Gurira the prominence they deserve but, as in the rest of the film, the good stuff ends up suffocated by unrefined plots, constant on-the-nose-ness... [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Ricardo Rosado

reviews.text: Coogler tries to deliver a parallel character dynamic with Shuri and Namor, and for a brief moment he succeeds... But sadly the formula of an MCU film demands something epic for the third act and that's where the film flounders on multiple levels.
reviews.author: Beth Accomando

reviews.text: It offers a powerful tribute to Chadwick Boseman, but Black Panther: Wakanda Forever sometimes feels like an MCU movie drowning in uncertainty.
reviews.author: Rick Marshall

reviews.text: It is a convoluted and tangled, well-intended jumble that is punctuated with out-of-place set pieces, every bit of which works individually while failing to congeal into a whole. It is almost as forgivably flawed as a broken human heart. Almost...
reviews.author: Ryan Syrek

reviews.text: It very much succeeds … while also being a rip-roaring Black Panther movie. Again, this movie is a miracle.
reviews.author: Mike Ryan

reviews.text: An extremely emotional and mature sequel, which deals with themes such as death, revenge and pain in a sufficiently elegant way, without forgetting that it is an action-packed superhero blockbuster. Full review in Spanish.
reviews.author: Sebastian Zavala Kahn

reviews.text: By incorporating the loss of Boseman into the storyline, Wakanda Forever becomes a memorial ceremony, one that remembers and celebrates their brother while respectfully moving forward...I also dare anyone going to see it to leave with dry eyes.
reviews.author: Damond Fudge

reviews.text: A thoughtful and mature exploration of communal grief in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is a fitting tribute to the legacy of Chadwick Boseman.
reviews.author: Sheri Flanders

reviews.text: Flies beyond the confines of the MCU as a thoughtful, resonant action-drama that serves as a strong hard-hitting poetic ode to Chadwick Boseman. Coogler and his team poured their soul to make this movie special.
reviews.author: Rendy Jones

reviews.text: A stunning tribute to the late Chadwick Boseman.
reviews.author: Aramide Tinubu

reviews.text: Black Panther works best when it is a drama focused on grief and loss. It’s when Kevin Feige’s Disney/MCU machine steps in to demand CGI action that the film becomes just another entry in the franchise’s multi-phased plan.
reviews.author: Joe Lipsett

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever pulls off the seemingly impossible by paying respect and giving emotional weight to the loss of Boseman, while confidently carving it's unexpected path to the future. A bloated runtime but one of the MCU's most emotional and mature films.
reviews.author: Cody Leach

reviews.text: The writing is thoughtful and piercing. At one point a grieving Shuri is told, "The world has taken too much from you for you to be considered a child." You are bound to get teary-eyed several times.
reviews.author: Renuka Vyavahare

reviews.text: The passing of a key character in Wakanda Forever should have created tears. Yet it has been presented in such a pedestrian manner that it generates no heartfelt sense of loss.
reviews.author: Dann Gire

reviews.text: Above all, the understated "feminist power" ... is to be valued. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Denise Pieniazek

reviews.text: A rousing exploration of multi-layered loss.
reviews.author: Nandini Ramnath

reviews.text: Fans of the MCU will doubtless embrace this at times moving sequel in a big way; for more serious cinemagoers this will remain a foreign country.
reviews.author: David Stratton

reviews.text: The film dances clumsily around greatness, instead giving us something good enough. Hey, Oscar-winner Ruth Carter’s costumes are still among the greatest ever created, and that matters a great deal to me.
reviews.author: Steven Prokopy

reviews.text: If this is what a Coogler misfire looks like, then it's still more entertaining than many of the adventures in the Marvel Universe.
reviews.author: Max Covill

reviews.text: This might be close to reaching peak potential of the MCU itself, a fantastic mix of drama, action, humor, and strength that’s far more focused on the humanity of its characters than the position of the MCU timeline.
reviews.author: Johnny Gayzmonic

reviews.text: The underwater sequences intended to visualize Talokan are drab and washed-out to the point of distraction, and even a street-level car chase shot at night is near-impossible to track, all the darkness seemingly intended to cover for lackluster CGI.
reviews.author: Isaac Feldberg

reviews.text: A bit overlong and narratively messy, but as engaging and satisfying a sequel as was feasibly possible given the loss of Chadwick Boseman. And the women of Wakanda get a chance to step into the spotlight.
reviews.author: Christopher Lloyd

reviews.text: A good Marvel film with great parts. More focus could have yielded a more powerful film.
reviews.author: Dan Murrell

reviews.text: Coogler’s script has plenty of tear-inducing moments and one mid-credit scene that will turn most into blubbering fools. Additionally, he finds a way to add a couple of clever surprises.
reviews.author: George M. Thomas

reviews.text: It’s a heartfelt film about love, loss, and legacy; one that honors Boseman in the best way possible and pulls off the impossible as it pivots the future of the franchise in his absence.
reviews.author: Matt Rodriguez

reviews.text: Through the fight with Namor, Wakanda Forever again crafts a conflict where the antagonist, bloodthirsty though he may be, isn't wrong, exactly, when it comes to the threat of colonialism and oppression.
reviews.author: Eric Webb

reviews.text: Thrilling, complex and layered beautifully with the many emotions that grief can bring.
reviews.author: Tatat Bunnag

reviews.text: Carried off in grand style and seriousness, this is a worthy tribute to the great Boseman and a MCU movie with heart and soul.
reviews.author: Alan Corr

reviews.text: Where Wakanda Forever works best it leans into its pathos, something of an untapped resource across the Marvel stable at large. Angela Bassett, as T'Challa's grieving mother, is the glue that holds the movie together.
reviews.author: Jack King

reviews.text: "Black Panther: Wakanda Forever" pays tribute to Chadwick Boseman, who will never be forgotten. For the MCU however, it's keep on rolling. New blood, new mantle, new characters, but at the end, it's the same old same old.
reviews.author: Tom Santilli

reviews.text: High tension for almost three hours without subtlety or relief; director Ryan Coogler laid it on thick but did give us a satisfying tribute to the late, great Black Panther and hope for the future.
reviews.author: Anne Brodie

reviews.text: Society tends to idealize Black female resilience, especially on screen, but the impression here is more nuanced, human.
reviews.author: Janelle Okwodu

reviews.text: Coogler puts all the pieces together in a way that makes Wakanda Forever feel like more of an epic than its predecessor, even if the special effects don’t necessarily support that thesis.
reviews.author: Ian Thomas Malone

reviews.text: An enjoyable watch at times and really rough at other times.
reviews.author: Dante James

reviews.text: A blockbuster that, within its spectacular nature, does not forget its discourse on identity. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Carlos Del Río

reviews.text: The weight of the story is unfairly placed on the narrow shoulders of T'Challa's brainy little sister Shuri, played by Letitia Wright, who just doesn’t have the gravitas to sustain the movie for its unwieldy two-hours and 41 minutes.
reviews.author: Lisa Johnson Mandell

reviews.text: The film frames itself within reign disputes, intrigue, traitors, and the enormous weight of ambition and responsibility. Its predecessor did so too, but this one goes further. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Diego Conesa

reviews.text: Almost like being at a funeral while trying to shush the kids who are playing with their Iron Man toys. ... It's more fascinating than your average comic book movie, even though it doesn't work as a comic book movie.
reviews.author: Radheyan Simonpillai

reviews.text: Writer/Director Ryan Coogler, paying so much screen time in tribute to the memory of the original Black Panther, creates and affects the heavy-hearted tenor of this film from beginning to end.
reviews.author: Linda and Al Lerner

reviews.text: It will break your heart, but it will also fill your heart with hope again and leave you cheering as the torch is passed to a new generation who surely make their fallen King proud.
reviews.author: Mark Hughes

reviews.text: Coogler pours his heart into every sequence of the film. This is not just a swansong for Boseman but a celebration of life in all its forms. *SPOILER FREE REVIEW*
reviews.author: Alan French

reviews.text: The Chadwick Boseman/T’Challa tributes are memorable and beautifully crafted, but ‘Wakanda Forever’ is cluttered, slow, and largely conversational (during the first two acts), as the story attempts to maneuver around its star’s passing.
reviews.author: Jeff Mitchell

reviews.text: The tone is wholly more grave than gratifying. The first film was able to weave inspired comedy and breathless action into the pointed narrative, but this sequel huffs and puffs trying to lighten its load.
reviews.author: Jeff York

reviews.text: “Wakanda Forever” is about reassessing yourself and your culture after disaster, acknowledging your strengths and building your future upon them, something this film models to great effect.
reviews.author: Charles Koplinski

reviews.text: The late Chadwick Boseman is never far from our minds as we watch what is both a fitting tribute to him — and to the character with which he had become most associated — and a satisfying action-filled superhero story.
reviews.author: Mark Meszoros

reviews.text: Things dragged on so long that by the time the mantle of Black Panther was passed to its new owner, I was like, “Okay. So that happened.” What was meant to be the movie’s big moment elicited little more than a shrug.
reviews.author: Collin Garbarino

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever ranks among Marvel Studios' best movies, and is an emotional, uplifting, tour de force of a blockbuster. Letitia Wright delivers a powerhouse performance, while Angela Bassett’s majestic work will leave you reeling.
reviews.author: Josh Wilding

reviews.text: 'Black Panther: Wakanda Forever' is simply sublime. It's a magnificent addition to the MCU, elevating its filmography as much as its predecessor. Tenoch Huerta and Angela Bassett are the heart and soul of this film.
reviews.author: Josie Meléndez

reviews.text: Letitia Wright and Angela Bassett elevate an overstuffed screenplay to deliver a moving tribute to Chadwick Boseman.
reviews.author: Aaron Peterson

reviews.text: Is Black supremacy better than White supremacy? And then there's a bit of worrisome cultural appropriation and questionable ascension issues.
reviews.author: Jana Monji

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever feels like the surest step taken in the MCU since Thanos was reduced to ash.
reviews.author: Michael Burgin

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever seems to have taken the lessons from its predecessor’s success and thrown them right in the trash.
reviews.author: Sonny Bunch

reviews.text: It can’t top the original and the absence of Chadwick Boseman hurts real bad, but Ryan Coogler’s sequel proves to be more than cringey franchise building by putting women of color in charge (yay to Angela Bassett and Letitia Wright) and watching them fly.
reviews.author: Peter Travers

reviews.text: The story ... is one of grief and mourning, of searching for answers and the desire for cultural and personal vengeance.
reviews.author: Sean Collier

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is a grief-forged geopolitical thriller that centers its characters’ emotional states.
reviews.author: Ryan Silberstein

reviews.text: Even with a new Black Panther, Wakanda still feels lost and hollow.
reviews.author: Phil Villarreal

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is exciting and visually striking but held back by its political hollowness, scenes that are difficult to see, and an unnecessarily long runtime.
reviews.author: Kyle Logan

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever is ... unable to hammer home its themes in a meaningful and resonant way like the original managed to. Ultimately, it's too much like standard Marvel fare.
reviews.author: Akhil Arora

reviews.text: A fair amount of spirited fun, but, frankly, it is too thinly stretched by a running-time that left me as weary as if I had gone head-to-head myself with the formidable Namor.
reviews.author: Brian Viner

reviews.text: An unusually mournful superhero movie powered by touching performances rather than the obligatory CGI action scenes.
reviews.author: Andy Lea

reviews.text: Black Panther Wakanda Forever has some incredible acting and IMAX action sequences but struggles to work without its late great star Chadwick Boseman.
reviews.author: George Simpson

reviews.text: For all its comic-book violence, over-the-top villainy, and too dark CGI, at its core this is a film about dealing with loss.
reviews.author: Odie Henderson

reviews.text: “Wakanda Forever” is the first blockbuster wake, and it’s powered not by vibranium but by its vibrant and fully felt emotions.
reviews.author: Ty Burr

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever doesn’t have all the answers, but few MCU films have more thoughtfully, or more honestly pushed themselves to reckon with how hard it can be to confront the kinds of questions that it does.
reviews.author: Gayle Sequeira

reviews.text: This return to Wakanda is indeed a beautifully elegiac and emotional homage to Boseman, but it does not quite succeed at being a worthy sequel to the original.
reviews.author: Kshitij Rawat

reviews.text: Puts women at the forefront rather than recasting its titular hero as some other dude, drawing on the talents of the supporting cast that was present but somewhat kept in the background on the first outing.
reviews.author: Charles Lyons-Burt

reviews.text: Marvel and Director Ryan Coogler shoulder an impossible task and come away with a strange yet captivating sci-fi/fantasy ensemble mini-epic about grief and loss that embodies the best of what the genre and this team in particular are capable of.
reviews.author: Bob Chipman

reviews.text: Visually engaging and girl-power savvy, “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever” is at its most heartfelt grieving for its king, and the larger-than-life actor whose absence is deeply felt.
reviews.author: Lynn Venhaus

reviews.text: “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever” is a crowd-pleasing superhero saga that will undoubtedly give the box office a super-powered boost.
reviews.author: Russ Simmons

reviews.text: BLACK PANTHER: WAKANDA FOREVER is at its best when focusing on the main female characters and their processing of their profound grief over the loss of King T’Challa.
reviews.author: Jeanne Kaplan

reviews.text: A stunningly beautiful film, but at two hours and 41 minutes it unfortunately includes some rather boring scenes.
reviews.author: David Kaplan

reviews.text: There were multiple story points and characters that were undeveloped, but the film still had enough energy from Angela Bassett and Tenoch Huerta to make it enjoyable. RIP Chadwick Boseman.
reviews.author: Brandon Avery

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever has the unenviable task of continuing on without its star but, in reckoning with that, it loses focus on how it wants to go forward.
reviews.author: Julian Lytle

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever is easily the best Marvel film since Avengers: Endgame. The scope, the camera work, the acting, and the raw emotions on and off screen can be felt throughout! This is the Marvel I’ve missed! I had one word in my heart all night; “WOW…”
reviews.author: Samuel Leggett Jr.

reviews.text: The action is handled decently and the special effects are top-notch, but it's the less "exciting" material that makes the film work, namely that of the aforementioned grief that pulses throughout the film.
reviews.author: Jim Judy

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever is a beautiful, moving film with highs and lows.
reviews.author: Latoya Austin

reviews.text: It’ll be up to wearisome nerds like me to point out the sequel’s shortcomings, but I’ll also say the movie helps us grieve the actor and the character both taken from us too soon. Don’t underestimate what that means.
reviews.author: Kristian M. Lin

reviews.text: Meeting head-on the complexities of the occasion... Black Panther: Wakanda Forever proves to be one of the more effective recent chapters in the never-ending Marvel story.
reviews.author: Keva York

reviews.text: Unfortunately, “Wakanda Forever” is a movie with a hole at its center. Boseman’s T’Challa is gone, and the movie doesn’t know how to get around that problem.
reviews.author: Roger Friedman

reviews.text: Single tears or floods of sobs performed by a clearly deeply affected cast are shown in close-up to convey pain and sorrow in such a raw manner that it’s difficult not to get invested in this epic and often breathtakingly arresting adventure.
reviews.author: Katherine McLaughlin

reviews.text: The expression of loss over the passing of King T’Challa and Chadwick Boseman is deep and heartfelt, and perhaps the most moving expression of mourning in cinema in recent memory.
reviews.author: John Lui

reviews.text: As always with Marvel -- particularly these films -- the design, costuming and choreography are all stunning. The music, by Ludwig Göransson and many collaborators, is the first Marvel score I've been tempted to buy.
reviews.author: Graeme Tuckett

reviews.text: It’s far from perfect, but very enjoyable, and the sadness that underlays everything feels real.
reviews.author: Paul Whitington

reviews.text: Exciting though it all may be (and it sure is), some of it nevertheless drags, even as we begin to approach the answer to the central question that brought us here.
reviews.author: Christopher Llewellyn Reed

reviews.text: It's unclear as to whether or not you're seeing the [characters] grieve or the [actors] grieve... in a way that enhanced the experience.
reviews.author: Jeremy Jahns

reviews.text: A love letter to Motherhood and the creation of a vehicle that would allow us to honor our fallen hero while introducing us to new characters.
reviews.author: Kathia Woods

reviews.text: It's difficult to think of another instance of an actor's death impacting a movie's plot to this degree, and you can't deny that the film is at its most powerful when it stops to honour Boseman.
reviews.author: Dominic Corry

reviews.text: Energetic and massively vibrant and humane, the film focuses on just one world, and for once, doesn't seem to have much to do with the rest of the MCU. And it works all the better for it. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Marcelo Stiletano

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever is warm, exciting, and a heartfelt tribute but I might’ve liked it more if it had done less.
reviews.author: Sherin Nicole

reviews.text: Fans of Marvel's long, fabled history will rejoice in finally seeing one of the very first Marvel superheroes, Namor the Sub-Mariner, on the screen, and only the most close-minded will not be able to enjoy his reinvention.
reviews.author: Don Kaye

reviews.text: Even when everything changes, nothing does. Yet if Wakanda Forever is Marvel striving to stay on course, it’s also a genuine departure from almost everything that has preceded it, and for that reason alone, should be seen.
reviews.author: Jake Wilson

reviews.text: Can be admired for its ambition, but it’s grindingly melancholy, with no sense of joy: the crushing mood of grief, as well as the emphasis on pointless, murderous conflict, make it difficult to enjoy on an elemental superhero level.
reviews.author: Frank Swietek

reviews.text: It may not be quite at the level of its predecessor, but it is still pretty special.
reviews.author: Micheal Compton

reviews.text: Coogler and company haven’t made a perfect Marvel movie, but they have made one that channels loss into thought-provoking artistry.
reviews.author: Caroline Siede

reviews.text: While less uplifting than the previous film, Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is moving, entertaining, and cathartic; stunning in its visual splendor and phenomenal acting.
reviews.author: DarkSkyLady

reviews.text: Boseman was the soul of Wakanda, and though his absence is felt, Wakanda Forever respectfully and thoughtfully carries his spirit on for future generations.
reviews.author: Rachel Ho

reviews.text: Writer/director Ryan Coogler returns and spends the bulk of the movie having the supporting cast grappling with the death of their leader, respectably making “Wakanda Forever” the first $200 million movie about grief.
reviews.author: Mathew DeKinder

reviews.text: To a much greater degree than I would have thought possible, Wakanda Forever is a gajillion-dollar comic-book blockbuster about something as complex and interior as the act of female mourning, split among at least four different strong woman protagonists.
reviews.author: Dana Stevens

reviews.text: Coogler does almost the impossible; he makes a movie that is a thrilling comic book adaptation while also honoring his friend and collaborator. This feat is nothing short of remarkable. Viewers will likely shed tears.
reviews.author: Jonathan W. Hickman

reviews.text: Everything looks great, but it is in the dramatic elements where the film shines, particularly in Shuri's [Letitia Wright] suffering and all the women who fight for Wakanda. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Pablo O. Scholz

reviews.text: Director/co-writer Ryan Coogler packed each of the 141 minutes of "Wakanda" with good stuff.
reviews.author: Chris Hewitt

reviews.text: rom the start, there is an elegiac tone, a strong sense of family ties rooted in the past, and a determination, however hard, to move forward -- and, damn it, still entertain.
reviews.author: Thelma Adams

reviews.text: Despite all the often empty bombast and bluster, it is in the moments of silence where the film still manages to strike a chord that serves as an emotional echo of what could have been.
reviews.author: Chase Hutchinson

reviews.text: Tragedy has always been an easy win for Marvel, laying waste to worlds so that chiselled heroes can gaze damp-eyed into the middle distance. Now, real life has shocked the glib out of the operation. For the first time... the tears actually mean something.
reviews.author: Danny Leigh

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever is, ultimately, a weary drag. It is as if the James Bond franchise had gone straight from Dr No to Moonraker in one leap (but with fewer jokes).
reviews.author: Donald Clarke

reviews.text: The movie is juggling way too much for anything but the most significant details to have much weight.
reviews.author: Mark Dujsik

reviews.text: In fits and starts “Wakanda Forever” continues the first movie’s dialogue about intergenerational burdens in the face of great power and responsibility.
reviews.author: David Lynch

reviews.text: Despite the best efforts of a dedicated cast and an inarguably talented writer/director ... Wakanda Forever lands as an at-times sluggish, unfocused struggle with the demands of both manifest destiny and grief, in both cases literally and figuratively.
reviews.author: Matt Lynch

reviews.text: Yes, 'Wakanda Forever' is another entry in the seemingly never-ending parade of content within these phases. But audiences will find tenderness and acknowledgment to those we have lost, which may make it okay to let our burdens down and feel.
reviews.author: Murjani Rawls

reviews.text: A moving, if at times muddled tribute that doesn’t skimp on the storytelling.
reviews.author: Cheyenne Bunsie

reviews.text: In overcoming the odds and occasional stumbles, Coogler’s profound film is both heartfelt and spiritually rewarding as a fitting tribute to Chadwick Boseman and the resilience of Black womanhood.
reviews.author: Kelechi Ehenulo

reviews.text: Given how emotionally numbing much of the mulch stamped out by Marvel can be – and that’s not a putdown, necessarily – the film chimes in as a stylish, finely honed, touching entry into the MCU, which is otherwise cluttered with cartoony time killers.
reviews.author: Jim Schembri

reviews.text: The mix of the intimate and epic is what makes Wakanda Forever work, both as a tribute to Chadwick Boseman and as blockbuster entertainment.
reviews.author: Richard Crouse

reviews.text: Ryan Coogler’s Marvel epic is a thoughtful, emotional and weighty film, an open-hearted story that courses with collective pain.
reviews.author: Wenlei Ma

reviews.text: The performances are slotted into the plot like puzzle pieces. The script is the main product, and it’s engineered with the precision of a high-tech machine, with all the artificial artistry to match.
reviews.author: Richard Brody

reviews.text: It’s a frustrating example of how financial success, not creative impetus, drives the existence of sequels, and it illustrates how unwieldy, contradictory, and overstuffed the MCU has become.
reviews.author: James Berardinelli

reviews.text: Although Black Panther: Wakanda Forever doesn’t fully reach the lofty heights of its predecessor, it is easily one of the most watchable Marvel films of recent years...it also serves as a deeply moving ode to the late Boseman.
reviews.author: Katie Smith-Wong

reviews.text: If you're looking for a big plus about the film, it makes the viewer think in a serious way about dealing with grief in their own lives.
reviews.author: Dennis Schwartz

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever nicely threads the needle of the superhero sequel, giving us more of what made the original so enjoyable while adding some powerful new faces to the mix.
reviews.author: Chris Knight

reviews.text: Great acting by Lupita Nyong'o and Danai Gurira, plus spectacular costumes by Ruth Carter, save this movie whose central plotline of enmity between two colonized peoples is meandering and unconvincing
reviews.author: J. Don Birnam

reviews.text: There’s both a comfort and a welcome surprise in knowing that after so many films and streaming shows (especially with this latest phase) the MCU still know how to tell a story first and serve as a spectacle second.
reviews.author: Peter Gray

reviews.text: “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever” is like interrupting that unmistakably joyous and sorrowful feeling at a wake with a live infomercial.
reviews.author: Blake Howard

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever is a balm to the very soul that puts Black healing front and center, while also inviting Latine people to the stage, so we can all move forward in this journey towards meaningful representation.
reviews.author: Lyra Hale

reviews.text: While Black Panther: Wakanda Forever has every excuse to be a messy and disappointing feature, the final result is shockingly focused with a natural thematic evolution from the first film being paired with a consistency not always seen within the MCU.
reviews.author: Carson Timar

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever is far from a failure, except that where there should be excellence, there is a middling feeling of watching something spectacularly competent.
reviews.author: Thom Ernst

reviews.text: Coogler leaves it to the women of Wakanda, often the scene-stealers of the original film, to take the lead in stitching the kingdom’s wounds.
reviews.author: Courtney Small

reviews.text: I don’t think it’s as strong as the first one, but it’s really good, especially given everything they were juggling here. It’s very weighty, very emotional, and there are moments that made me tear up.
reviews.author: Eric Goldman

reviews.text: [Ryan] Coogler strikes an affecting balance between spectacle and elegy.
reviews.author: Jeffrey Zhang

reviews.text: Although it’s a marked step down from its game changing predecessor, Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is still a cut above the recent slate of superhero blockbusters, thanks to some tremendous performances and strong direction.
reviews.author: Andrew Parker

reviews.text: It’s both a tribute to the late Chadwick Boseman and a problem for the movie that “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever” feels his loss so keenly.
reviews.author: Peter Howell

reviews.text: A Marvel movie, for sure. But a pretty interesting one, partly because it’s also a Ryan Coogler film, with the director’s signature interplay of genre touchstones, vivid emotions, and allegorical implications.
reviews.author: A.O. Scott

reviews.text: The fresh momentum generated here all but guarantees the Black Panther effect will continue to prowl and pounce for some time to come.
reviews.author: Leigh Paatsch

reviews.text: For all its faults, Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is still the most watchable of the recent slate of MCU films. The film wears its emotions on its sleeve, giving fans permission to publicly grieve the generational talent gone too soon.
reviews.author: Alex Bentley

reviews.text: Letitia Wright excels when she takes the spotlight. However, the rest of the bloated, messy runtime is at odds with multiple other shoehorned subplots and suffers from dealing with too many characters.
reviews.author: Jeffrey Harris

reviews.text: Regrettably, Black Panther: Wakanda Forever tries to do so many things that it comes across as threadbare and pallid — less a failure of imagination and more of circumstance, time, and narrative constraints.
reviews.author: Angelica Jade Bastién

reviews.text: A mercurial sequel that can’t match its predecessor.
reviews.author: Philip De Semlyen

reviews.text: In a Hollywood studio landscape that feels increasingly homogenized, it’s something of a relief to see that one of these can still have genuine soul, even if it’s eventually squandered.
reviews.author: Siddhant Adlakha

reviews.text: Even as he delivers the obligatory spectacle, Coogler interweaves both storylines, the macro and the micro, deftly, giving each one room to develop organically.
reviews.author: Mel Valentin

reviews.text: “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever” might have its heart in the right place but is in the wrong mindset and in the worst space—at the center of a contrived cinematic universe—to mourn on its own terms.
reviews.author: Robert Daniels

reviews.text: Yes, it's trying to process loss and grief, but is a Marvel blockbuster really going to be able to grapple with it effectively? Whether it is or not is debatable, but the fact is that it is forced to try.
reviews.author: Brian Lloyd

reviews.text: While Boseman’s absence is definitely felt, most of the incredibly talented cast from the first film returns elevating the level of acting throughout the film.
reviews.author: Allison Rose

reviews.text: A valiant attempt to move forward without the predecessor's enigmatic leader.
reviews.author: Doug Jamieson

reviews.text: Chadwick Boseman is deeply missed in a sequel that still checks all the right boxes for Marvel fans.
reviews.author: Rafer Guzman

reviews.text: “Wakanda Forever” winds up feeling hopelessly stalled, covering up an inability to move on by resorting to repetitive, over-familiar action sequences, maudlin emotional beats and an uninvolving, occasionally incoherent story.
reviews.author: Ann Hornaday

reviews.text: There’s real emotion in the best material here. The loss of Boseman was enormous. So is the skill level of the actors, returning and new, who make the most of a pretty good sequel.
reviews.author: Michael Phillips

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever stands out from a somewhat formulaic era of Marvel movies: held together by its compelling sense of place, and by acting as a passionate eulogy for Chadwick Boseman.
reviews.author: Kambole Campbell

reviews.text: "The fact Wakanda Forever works at all is impressive. The fact it almost matches its exceptional predecessor is nothing short of a triumph."
reviews.author: Tom Beasley

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever is unlike any movie we've seen in the MCU. I'm so grateful for this level of black representation that doesn't focus on our suffering or exploiting our stereotypes.
reviews.author: Korey Coleman

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever emerged as one of the best Marvel movies to date [and] also a much-needed boost of faith and quality — something that the MCU Phase 4 has been such a bumpy ride after the post-Endgame era.
reviews.author: Casey Chong

reviews.text: It's a sequel that bores me in perpetuity with its abundance of one-dimensional female characters and, most of all, bland action that exposes the anthropological side of Marvel without any sense of wonder. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Yasser Medina

reviews.text: It’s cool that even a behemoth corporate beast like Disney allowed the film to break the MCU’s norms to honour Boseman in the way it does. It’s genuinely beautiful.
reviews.author: Daniel Rutledge

reviews.text: This is an often moving story of a lot of characters with too much going on as they struggle to find focus after the death of the central figure in their lives. There's plenty of high points, but things can occasionally feel a little strained
reviews.author: Anthony Morris

reviews.text: An imperfect but mature blockbuster that balances resonant drama with vibrant spectacle. [Full Review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Nestor Bentancor

reviews.text: Ultimately, Black Panther: Wakanda Forever won't be remembered for its exhilarating action, stunning CGI or palpable thrills, but rather for its genuinely heartfelt moments of melancholy and tenderness.
reviews.author: Avi Offer

reviews.text: Coogler, who dedicates the film to Boseman, has created a film that allows us to mourn the loss of this elegant actor. Themes of grief and moving forward loom large in the film, while actors like Wright and Bassett grow with their expanded roles.
reviews.author: James Mottram

reviews.text: The latest installment struggles with a less charismatic villain and too many MCU threads.
reviews.author: Alan Zilberman

reviews.text: There’s a smaller story about solace buried somewhere in here, but Phase Four has no interest in that.
reviews.author: Josh Larsen

reviews.text: It goes to show that even the most well-oiled, if decreasingly impressive machine can pump out something exceptional if the right talent is turning the crank.
reviews.author: Dan Scully

reviews.text: Black Panther Wakanda Forever is deeply impactful at honoring the legacy of an important king, the healing the comes from that for a community and forging a new path for these characters. It’s a grounded and epic ending for the inconsistent Phase 4.
reviews.author: Paul McGuire Grimes

reviews.text: Coogler knows how to cut to the core of humanizing these larger-than-life characters and illuminate what they are fighting for with real-world relevancy. He’s two for two in creating layered heroes and antiheroes
reviews.author: Robert Kojder

reviews.text: This is an emotionally resonant work, brimming with subtext and nuance and exhibiting none of the empty quippiness these films rely on all too often.
reviews.author: Anthony O'Connor

reviews.text: “Wakanda Forever” isn’t as invigorating as “Black Panther,” which is to be expected, with the MCU formula fighting to keep the endeavor exciting when it eventually sags, though the bigness of the final 30 minutes is impressive.
reviews.author: Brian Orndorf

reviews.text: In more ways than one, Black Panther: Wakanda Forever shows how healing from a tragedy can turn into a triumph. This top-notch sequel to 2018’s Black Panther is an epic story of grief, loyalty, greed, and the resilience of the human spirit.
reviews.author: Carla Hay

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is an emotionally gripping film, that makes the best of what it can given the tragic hand it was dealt.
reviews.author: Emmanuel Noisette

reviews.text: As it stands, “Wakanda Forever” feels as lost and forlorn as the Wakandan people.
reviews.author: Mick LaSalle

reviews.text: When Wakanda Forever gets to lean into the more genuine, earnest, and nuanced aspects of its story and characters is when it really shines.
reviews.author: Alejandra Martinez

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever feels like it goes on forever, but despite an extremely slow paced setup, director / screenwriter Ryan Coogler has enough beauty and tragic intrigue amongst invigorating action that will appeal to Marvel fans.
reviews.author: Jason Escamilla

reviews.text: Coogler and Cole's screenplay set up familiar dilemmas without being repetitive. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Mikel Zorrilla

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever proves poignant in two ways: the film is often quite thoughtful in its exploration of grief, but it struggles to overcome what the actor's loss means to the future of this series.
reviews.author: Tim Grierson

reviews.text: The true “prestige” Marvel picture it borders on being less a film continuing themes that resonated with audiences and, rather, about itself, resulting in artistic tensions both interesting and frustrating.
reviews.author: Ethan Vestby

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever is overlong, a little unwieldy... But Coogler’s fluid command of mixing intimacy with spectacle remains gripping.
reviews.author: Jake Coyle

reviews.text: It is to Coogler’s credit that the movie manages to be as entertaining as it is. But it would take more than a heart-shaped herb to give the final product the power to keep the seams from showing
reviews.author: Luke Y. Thompson

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever , in short, faces the same dilemmas as the previous film, but has lost any poise to combat them. [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Alberto Corona

reviews.text: Presented the daunting task of bidding farewell to a star tragically taken in his prime in sober but stirring fashion, Coogler has given audiences, and the studio, a solidly and gracefully executed dive into a “Wakanda” for right now.
reviews.author: Brian Lowry

reviews.text: Certainly, the film has its high points but, ultimately, it pales in comparison to its predecessor, one of the best entries in the field of superhero cinema, and feels largely like a placeholder for the next movie.
reviews.author: Cary Darling

reviews.text: What audiences receive with "Wakanda Forever" is herculean, succeeding in quelling all voices, telling a tale that serves as an emotional and personal arc for the Wakandans, and setting the stage for an incursion of devastating proportions.
reviews.author: Douglas Davidson

reviews.text: It’s a movie about not seeing beyond your own grief... Every narrative tendril is implicated in grief, from historical colonialism to environmental exploitation to political repression.
reviews.author: Kevin Maher

reviews.text: The sequel honors Chadwick Boseman and respectfully hands down the baton to the next in line. It’s a thoughtful script, and like the first movie, Coogler interweaves superheroism with social commentary.
reviews.author: Lupe Rodriguez Haas

reviews.text: Wakanda is more than just a great sequel; it is one of the most heartfelt and moving tributes to an actor I’ve had the pleasure to witness.
reviews.author: JimmyO

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever throws many emotional challenges at its heroes -- self-doubt, anguish, ennui -- and in Namor, it gives them an adversary brimming with assuredness. The result is a face-off that’s as entertaining as it is unpredictable.
reviews.author: David Sims

reviews.text: In a mythology where death is more often used as a narrative device than a true measure of loss, Black Panther: Wakanda Forever magnifies the truth that the title character’s world will endure, even if he doesn’t
reviews.author: Todd Gilchrist

reviews.text: Black Panther was already one of the MCU’s best properties, and the sequel keeps it that way. Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is one of Marvel’s finest films.
reviews.author: Dorian Parks

reviews.text: After multiple movies that, while entertaining, ultimately felt aimless and grasping, Wakanda Forever is cohesive and emotionally impacting regaining some of the MCU luster.
reviews.author: Therese Lacson

reviews.text: “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever” avoids the mistakes most sequels make, creating a different atmosphere and tone, elevating the MCU to much higher, ambitious places.
reviews.author: Randy Myers

reviews.text: BLACK PANTHER: WAKANDA FOREVER unfortunately doesn’t really come close to its strong predecessor. It imitates it far too much and never really gets going. In the end, the more than two and a half hours become a real test of patience.
reviews.author: Jimmy Cage

reviews.text: For long stretches, it feels like Wakanda Forever could have been more successful had it shucked its superhero confines: just trim the fat, make it a character/political drama set in the MCU, and ditch the gloppy CG action.
reviews.author: Clint Worthington

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever plays like the triumphant celebration of an idea, the mournful farewell to an actual hero, and a promise of even greater things to come all rolled into one.
reviews.author: Charles Pulliam-Moore

reviews.text: After a hearty start, the film sputters in its second half, dragging through its bloated runtime on its way to its at once overblown and underwhelming finale.
reviews.author: Adam Graham

reviews.text: “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever” is a movie about loss and moving on. It’s not as great a film as “Black Panther,” but it’s the right next step.
reviews.author: Bill Goodykoontz

reviews.text: In facing one of the highest degrees of difficulty for a filmmaker in recent history, Ryan Coogle has gotten most of the way there.
reviews.author: Stephen Silver

reviews.text: Though there's some plot messiness in the mix, Black Panther: Wakanda Forever undeniably delivers in terms of action, star power, and superhero spectacle. But what hit me hardest is its exploration of grief...
reviews.author: Kristy Puchko

reviews.text: Probably the best movie they could have possibly made under the circumstances of lead Chadwick Boseman's death. What could have been with a Boseman sequel is part and parcel of this version.
reviews.author: Fred Topel

reviews.text: The repetitive pattern of identifying a quandary, then whipping up a hi-tech answer, grows maddeningly frivolous – especially over the course of 160 minutes.
reviews.author: Mike Massie

reviews.text: Superhero films are rarely imbued with this level of emotional resonance and gravitas, and even though it doesn't reach the heights of the original Black Panther, it's still head and shoulders above the MCU's other post-Avengers: Endgame offerings.
reviews.author: Brent Hankins

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever makes for an emotional farewell to Boseman while carefully constructing a new path for the franchise.
reviews.author: Jeffrey Lyles

reviews.text: [It] doesn’t try to make us forget the noble T’Challa and his portrayer, Chadwick Boseman. But, by the end, you’re at least assured that his legacy is secure.
reviews.author: Sean P. Means

reviews.text: The film carries the unnecessary burden of setting up future projects with certain key characters. Fortunately, Ryan Coogler and the ensemble redeem the film with moving and sincere dramatic scenes... [Full review in Spanish]
reviews.author: Juanma Fernández París

reviews.text: This might not all be so deflating if Wakanda Forever worked, simply, as an action spectacle. But very little here pops.
reviews.author: Barry Hertz
