reviews.text: Between a fallen king and a rising threat, Marvel’s cinematic Phase 4 ends on a tender and – mostly - triumphant high.
reviews.author: Kevin Harley

reviews.text: The film improved on many issues I had with the first film while repeating some of those mistakes.
reviews.author: EJ Moreno

reviews.text: An emotionally powerful and cathartic cinematic journey of loss, grief, and moving forward. Tenoch Huerta, Angela Bassett, and Letitia Wright are the vibranium of the film: magnetic, powerful, and lasting.
reviews.author: David Gonzalez

reviews.text: Why, with most of the old pieces in place, does Wakanda Forever feel—as so many sequels before it have—like it's reflecting the magic of its predecessor rather than entirely recapturing it?
reviews.author: A.A. Dowd

reviews.text: This is a movie that would make T’Challa proud, and it is a worthy tribute to Boseman and to the Marvel writers and artists who first envisioned Wakanda and made us all want it to go on forever.
reviews.author: Nell Minow

reviews.text: An immensely powerful story of forging forward — shattering at times, but also beautifully cathartic, heartening, and very much earns that title.
reviews.author: Perri Nemiroff

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever will have you thinking about the many shapes that grief can take, and it comes at you from all fronts.
reviews.author: Britany Murphy

reviews.text: Not your typical superhero film, Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is a welcome departure from the MCU formula with emotional impact and importance, rich in culture and storytelling.
reviews.author: Tania Lamb

reviews.text: A powerful tribute to Chadwick Boseman. Stellar and emotional performance by the cast. While the cast delivered, Boseman's absence was definitely felt. Enjoyed the addition of Namor and Riri Williams as well as the huge action sequences.
reviews.author: Wendy Lee Szany

reviews.text: Despite being dealt a terrible hand, Coogler manages to deliver a cohesive, emotional, and satisfying follow up to the first film which ends MCU phase 4 on a high note.
reviews.author: Sean Chandler

reviews.text: Affecting, tender, and full of heart-pounding thrills and excitement, Coogler and team have produced the rare sequel that not only lives up to the original but raises the bar in a tremendous way.
reviews.author: Mark Johnson

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever dives deeper into it all and does so by actually creating a world stage with dangerous implications that raise the stakes for Wakandans and the rest of the surface world.
reviews.author: Kate Sánchez

reviews.text: The interpersonal storylines, the tackling of the connections between grief and rage and flight, are some of the deepest and most nuanced in the franchise's history.
reviews.author: Richard Whittaker

reviews.text: "With ruminations on personal loss and the pride of nations, Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is a monumental epic whose thematic and narrative maturity elevates the superhero genre to breathtaking new heights."
reviews.author: Eric Francisco

reviews.text: Chadwick Boseman may no longer be with us but the legacy of King T'Challa lives on in Marvel's Black Panther: Wakanda Forever.
reviews.author: Danielle Solzman

reviews.text: Somehow Coogler and the returning cast of Letitia Wright, Lupita Nyong’o, Danai Gurira, Angela Bassett and Winston Duke did it, creating a film that is emotional, enthralling and most of all, unapologetic.
reviews.author: Ron Seoul-Oh

reviews.text: There is much to be admired here, a care for craft and detail on a higher plane than other Marvel fare. Still, some will no doubt miss the tight focus and energy of Black Panther. This sequel is more scattered, a vast expansion with a hole at its center.
reviews.author: Richard Lawson

reviews.text: As with the first film, Wakanda Forever works best when it’s deviating from the expected tropes of a superhero film.
reviews.author: Alistair Harkness

reviews.text: You watch it wondering about the movie that never got made, the story that never got finished, the life cut short too soon.
reviews.author: Moira MacDonald

reviews.text: A messy sprawl of an ensemble piece.
reviews.author: Matt Singer

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is another phase four entry that is a bit of a mess in the story and pacing department, but it is bookended by gut-punch memorial scenes and excellent performances from the entire cast.
reviews.author: Kaitlyn Booth

reviews.text: "Wakanda Forever" is most comparable to "Avengers: Age of Ultron," another overstuffed sequel that doesn't quite hit the mark. However, Coogler at least lands the emotional core, with the help of a great new villain and an upgraded heroine.
reviews.author: Evan Dossey

reviews.text: This riotously poetic, serenely political and spectacularly cathartic yarn is the best blockbuster of the year. 2022 isn’t about Maverick anymore. It’s about mavericks.
reviews.author: Charlotte O'Sullivan

reviews.text: Wright is magnificent
reviews.author: Linda Marric

reviews.text: It’s telling that both the first “Black Panther” and this messier if seldom less engrossing follow-up are at their strongest when they resist or even flat-out ignore their franchise obligations.
reviews.author: Justin Chang

reviews.text: The movie isn’t always on such sure footing. But that’s almost appropriate: a messier movie trying to reckon with a messier range of feelings.
reviews.author: K. Austin Collins

reviews.text: [I]t’s a challenging and powerful cinematic expression of mourning that is utterly beautiful in its design.
reviews.author: Eric Eisenberg

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever is as emotionally fulfilling as that brilliant first trailer. Not only is this a beautifully-written script, but the cast crushes it. This is a sequel handled with care, and Coogler manages to raise his game from a direction standpoint.
reviews.author: Austin Burke

reviews.text: Ryan Coogler achieves remarkable feats with a powerfully emotional sequel that reshapes a blockbuster franchise. Black Panther: Wakanda Forever stands as the most mature and thoughtful film in the MCU.
reviews.author: Julian Roman

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever never quite matches the inspiring peaks of its predecessor, but it benefits immensely from its compassion... It’s a sequel whose greatest superpower turns out to be its sensitivity.
reviews.author: Nick Schager

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever succeeds as a new adventure, and as a tribute to a wonderful actor who was taken from this world decades too soon.
reviews.author: Richard Roeper

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever manages the delicate balancing act of working beautifully as a sequel to the 2018 movie, a touching tribute to Chadwick Boseman's character and a complex, thrilling MCU adventure.
reviews.author: Sean Keane

reviews.text: A dutiful, mirthless movie derailed by a real-life loss from which no franchise could feasibly recover.
reviews.author: Sean Burns

reviews.text: Though as long, noisy, and cluttered as any other superhero blockbuster, Wakanda Forever is a sincere and effective genre-mashing drama, and one of the better installments in the Marvel oeuvre.
reviews.author: Dylan Roth

reviews.text: Ticking boxes isn’t the same as pulling magic -- or even just insight -- from thin air... The sad reality is that the show must go on, and without [Chadwick Boseman], it’s just more of the same. Our job is to pretend it’s enough.
reviews.author: Stephanie Zacharek

reviews.text: A fantastic sequel about grief and true leadership with Shuri's journey. Ryan Coogler handles the passing of Chadwick Boseman quite well. Plus Namor is a fantastic addition with the MCU! One of Marvel's best.
reviews.author: Grace Randolph

reviews.text: While full of breathtaking visuals, a few truly shocking moments, and another Grammy-worthy soundtrack from Ludwig Göransson, the sequel wastes a decent portion of its lengthy two-hour-and-41-minute runtime on setting up spin-offs.
reviews.author: Kirsten Acuna

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is under a lot of pressure, but Coogler lands it. The performances are strong, and the stakes feel natural and internal.
reviews.author: Princess Weekes

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever has transformed tragedy into triumph.
reviews.author: Toussaint Egan

reviews.text: “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever’s” momentum ebbs and flows, but its powerful females move the franchise forward.
reviews.author: Laura Clifford

reviews.text: There can be no doubt Coogler has meticulously thought all of this out, while still delivering the rip roaring action sequences and uncredited surprise appearances we expect from any Marvel movie, but especially its crown jewel.
reviews.author: Pete Hammond

reviews.text: Through the collective efforts of a cast intent on doing right by the man who started it all, the film percolates with purpose. There is a new Black Panther, and they will figure into the future of this universe. After the credits, there's a big surprise
reviews.author: Aaron Perine

reviews.text: The stirring and thematically grounded “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever” not only finds a way to eulogize and honor Boseman’s life, but moves the sticks forward and cements it as one of the better, more recent Marvel entries.
reviews.author: Nate Adams

reviews.text: There’s more than enough wit, beauty, and imagination to Wakanda Forever to outweigh its weaknesses.
reviews.author: Clarisse Loughrey

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is by far the best film in phase 4 of the Marvel Cinematic Universe. Phase 5 has some big shoes to fill after this one, and hopefully, the storytelling can create the same kind of authenticity and greatness this movie has.
reviews.author: Jamie Broadnax

reviews.text: The movie doesn’t have the classic comic-book pow of Black Panther, and it’s easily 20 minutes too long. Yet Wakanda Forever has a slow-burn emotional suspense. Once the film starts to gather steam, it doesn’t let up.
reviews.author: Owen Gleiberman

reviews.text: “Wakanda Forever” solidifies Black Panther as Marvel’s richest and most high-quality franchise.
reviews.author: Johnny Oleksinski

reviews.text: “Show them who we are!” bellows like an angry warning at first, but in Ryan Coogler’s hands, this layered and thoughtful maxim eventually lands on forgiveness, love, and finding a way forward beyond despair.
reviews.author: Rodrigo Perez

reviews.text: There’s a great deal to enjoy here, and fans of “Black Panther” won’t necessarily leave feeling disappointed, but there’s a sense of strong elements not quite coming together.
reviews.author: Alonso Duralde

reviews.text: A near-three-hour endurance run of gloomy photography and turgidly staged, emotionally empty two-way conversations, all seemingly designed to sap cast and viewers’ combined will to live.
reviews.author: Robbie Collin

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is spectacular, emotional, visceral, and even cathartic.
reviews.author: M.N. Miller

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is an emotionally gratifying journey with diplomatic stakes that feel vigorous, despite an overcrowded narrative.
reviews.author: Jeff Nelson

reviews.text: Director Ryan Coogler delivers a powerful follow-up to the phenomenal 2018 Black Panther that’s funny, clever and heartbreaking, impressive in its world-building, honest in its view of world politics and naturally packed with huge action sequences.
reviews.author: Brian Truitt

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever isn’t perfect, but its ability to handle this tightrope walk between exploration of loss and a larger superhero film makes this one of the most moving MCU entries so far, and one of the best films to come out of Marvel’s Phase Four.
reviews.author: Ross Bonaime

reviews.text: A worthy continuation.
reviews.author: David Rooney

reviews.text: The specifics of Wakanda Forever’s long-winded plot will likely leave little impact, but that doesn’t stop the new Black Panther from standing tall.
reviews.author: Tom Jorgensen

reviews.text: The memory and spirit of the late Chadwick Boseman lift this sequel to emotional and dramatic heights rarely seen in the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
reviews.author: Joey Morona

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is every bit the cathartic experience we needed it to be, telling an exciting, deeply emotional story that allows us to come to terms with our feelings over Boseman.
reviews.author: Travis Hopson

reviews.text: Though messy at times, Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is an impactful examination of grief aided by excellent character work and exhilarating action.
reviews.author: Rachel LaBonte

reviews.text: As with the last film, there are bold extravagant gestures of spectacle, while Wright, Coel, Bassett, Gurira and Thorne all supply fierce performances; each of them ups the onscreen voltage simply by appearing.
reviews.author: Peter Bradshaw

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is the best sequel we could have hoped for without Chadwick Boseman. Ryan Coogler has built a respectful, mature, beautiful monument to his friend and T'Challa, whose legacy is in the safe hands of a worthy successor.
reviews.author: Mark Cassidy

reviews.text: While a Black Panther without Boseman is undoubtedly nothing like the film's creators or any of its cast wanted it to be, the movie they've made feels like something unusually elegant and profound for the multiplex.
reviews.author: Leah Greenblatt

reviews.text: All the criticisms that can be made of Wakanda Forever... ultimately end up seemingly meaningless compared to the sheer emotional wallop that is the way it handles Chadwick Boseman's passing.
reviews.author: Reuben Baron

reviews.text: That Black Panther: Wakanda Forever works completely defies logic. The film juggles so many storylines, so many characters, and so many emotions... it’s seemingly too much for any one movie to handle, but Wakanda Forever does it.
reviews.author: Germain Lussier

reviews.text: For all of the film’s shuddery pacing... Coogler’s subthread of the MCU continues to operate at a significantly higher strata of thought, artistry, and feeling than the rest of Marvel’s assembly line.
reviews.author: David Ehrlich

reviews.text: Ryan Coogler has somehow found a way to craft a worthy sequel to “Black Panther” that, at times, matches and at other times, even exceeds the original.
reviews.author: Matt Neglia

reviews.text: Many who find themselves somewhat bored with the recent glut of Marvel content have good enough reason to step back into the circle for another round with Coogler and his amazing friends.
reviews.author: Jon Negroni

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever works better overall than Black Panther ... Coogler can really focus on the emotions felt by himself and the cast towards the death of Boseman, while also introducing what could be some major Marvel players.
reviews.author: Edward Douglas

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is actually a real movie...a story about legacy and loss, complicated by real life grief and the guilt of carrying on.
reviews.author: Matt Oakes

reviews.text: Fantastic! Coogler delivers a soulful, wondrous sequel that packs an emotional punch and effectively explores relevant world themes. A beautiful tribute to Boseman's legacy, and the best offering from MCU's phase four. (Full review in Spanish)
reviews.author: Fico Cangiano

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever is a melancholy and moving meditation on loss and grief that is as cathartic for us as it is for the characters. Wright, Gurrira & Bassett are the movie's heart in Boseman's stead. Not by replacing him, but by reminding us of his impact.
reviews.author: Karl Delossantos

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is a masterclass in superhero storytelling. Emotionally rich and technically brilliant, Chadwick Boseman’s legacy is honored in a film that takes audiences and characters alike on a journey about grief, loss, and recovery.
reviews.author: Sheraz Farooqi

reviews.text: Ambitious in terms of scope and the emotional weight being confronted, Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is a powerful and often-times moving epic that stands tall alongside the previous film and serves as a beautiful tribute.
reviews.author: Brandon Zachary

reviews.text: A big, overstuffed, action-packed sequel.
reviews.author: Chris Evangelista

reviews.text: A powerful, emotional, and intense roller coaster, this film perfectly honors both Chadwick Boseman and T'Challa. The entire cast deserves nominations, but Angela Bassett and Letitia Wright stand out.
reviews.author: Tessa Smith

reviews.text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever is a moving tribute to Chadwick Boseman and one of Marvel's best epics to date.
reviews.author: Joey Magidson

reviews.text: For all the really cool imagery and fx, the film is really about characters and how they see themselves in the context of the world, not about big action sequences. A version of this film could have been made in the 1970s and would be just as effective.
reviews.author: David Poland

reviews.text: Marvel films already get likened to a circus enough, but the feeling and urgency matching the old saying of "the show must go on" are very much present with "Black Panther: Wakanda Forever."
reviews.author: Don Shanahan

reviews.text: Brimming with life and the sense of wonder these Marvel films so rarely achieve. Even if the demands of a franchise can leave this film feeling overstuffed, the effort to deliver a sincere superhero feature gives further meaning to "Wakanda Forever."
reviews.author: Aaron Neuwirth

reviews.text: Marvel’s Phase Four hasn’t been exactly the best era for the studio – Love & Thunder, am I right? – but with Black Panther: Wakanda Forever, they saved the best for last.
reviews.author: Sean Mulvihill

reviews.text: Wakanda Forever is masterfully and delicately handled. It doesn't sink under the weight of its uphill challenges, rather it rises to and exceeds expectations.
reviews.author: Janet A. Leigh

reviews.text: ...every emotional beat in Black Panther: Wakanda Forever still lands. They hit hard because they have been real for us. As a story of loss, legacy, and healing, Wakanda Forever is a beautiful sequel.
reviews.author: Kevin L. Lee

reviews.text: Though its lugubrious and plodding narrative spins its wheels ahead of someone coming along to fill T’Challa’s shoes, Wakanda Forever does stand out for its depictions of grief.
reviews.author: Jake Cole

reviews.text: The outpouring of raw emotion, the tears - all real. It's regal yet messy, refined and yet unrefined. This movie sequel is a grief journey with power beyond super heroes. Death is not the end of this king's legacy. It's just the beginning.
reviews.author: Christie Cronan

reviews.text: Has the muscle and heft of a comic-book blockbuster, but it also reflects profoundly on the human resonance of ancestry, remembering and moving on.
reviews.author: Neil Pond

synopsis: In Marvel Studios' "Black Panther: Wakanda Forever," Queen Ramonda (Angela Bassett), Shuri (Letitia Wright), M'Baku (Winston Duke), Okoye (Danai Gurira) and the Dora Milaje (including Florence Kasumba) fight to protect their nation from intervening world powers in the wake of King T'Challa's death. As the Wakandans strive to embrace their next chapter, the heroes must band together with the help of War Dog Nakia (Lupita Nyong'o) and Everett Ross (Martin Freeman) and forge a new path for the kingdom of Wakanda.
